questions.question: What is the capital of France?

Unscramble the letters for the answer: He/she helps the author to improve their written work such as a story, essay, poem, etc. (EDIOTR)
questions.explanation: An editor helps the author improve their written work.

questions.question: Unscramble the letters for the answer: A traditional short story that teaches a moral lesson. (ALFBE)
questions.explanation: A fable is a traditional short story that teaches a moral lesson.

questions.question: Unscramble the letters for the answer: The main printed part of a book/magazine. (XTTE)
questions.explanation: The text is the main printed part of a book or magazine.

questions.question: Unscramble the letters for the answer: A set of questions in a book to test your knowledge. (XCEESIRE)
questions.explanation: An exercise is a set of questions in a book to test your knowledge.

questions.question: Unscramble the letters for the answer: A word used for plays and theatre. (AADRM)
questions.explanation: Drama is a word used for plays and theatre.

questions.question: Unscramble the letters for the answer: The words of a song. (LYRCIS)
questions.explanation: Lyrics are the words of a song.

questions.question: Unscramble the letters for the answer: Many poems or stories together. (COTIONLLEC)
questions.explanation: A collection is many poems or stories together.

questions.question: Unscramble the letters for the answer: A writing partner. (OC-AUROTH)
questions.explanation: A co-author is a writing partner.

questions.question: In your own Find Out book, make a list like this: Who writes poems?
questions.explanation: A poet writes poems.

questions.question: In your own Find Out book, make a list like this: Who writes plays?
questions.explanation: A playwright writes plays.

questions.question: Find Out what these words mean: e-book, monograph, headline, caption, footnote.
questions.correct_answer: E-book: A digital version of a book; Monograph: A detailed written study on a single subject; Headline: The title of a news article; Caption: A brief explanation under a picture; Footnote: A note at the bottom of a page giving extra information.
questions.explanation: E-book: A digital version of a book; Monograph: A detailed written study on a single subject; Headline: The title of a news article; Caption: A brief explanation under a picture; Footnote: A note at the bottom of a page giving extra information.

questions.question: The Olympic symbol is five circles or rings joined together. What do the rings stand for?
questions.explanation: The five rings represent the five continents: Africa, Americas, Asia, Europe, and Oceania.

questions.question: What are the colors of the Olympic rings?
questions.explanation: The colors of the Olympic rings are blue, yellow, black, green, and red.

questions.question: Which Indian woman finished fourth in the golf event at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics?
questions.explanation: Aditi Ashok finished fourth in the golf event at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.

questions.question: Break dancing will be introduced as a new event in the Summer Olympics 2024. True or False.
questions.explanation: Break dancing will be introduced as a new event in the Summer Olympics 2024.

questions.question: Which country's team always marches last in the march past at the opening ceremony of the Olympics?
questions.explanation: The host country's team always marches last in the opening ceremony.

questions.question: Today's Olympic winners are presented with medals of gold, silver, or bronze. What were the winners in the ancient Olympics awarded?
questions.explanation: Winners in the ancient Olympics were awarded a crown of olive leaves.

questions.question: In which athletic event did Neeraj Chopra win a gold medal for India at the Tokyo Olympics 2020?
questions.explanation: Neeraj Chopra won a gold medal in the javelin throw at the Tokyo Olympics 2020.

questions.question: In which sport has India won eight Olympic golds, a silver, and three bronze medals?
questions.explanation: India has won eight Olympic golds, a silver, and three bronze medals in hockey.

questions.question: In which sport did Mirabai Chanu win a silver medal for India at the 2020 Tokyo Olympic Games?
questions.explanation: Mirabai Chanu won a silver medal in weightlifting at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.

questions.question: The Olympic motto is CITIUS, ALTIUS, FORTIUS. What does it mean?
questions.explanation: The Olympic motto CITIUS, ALTIUS, FORTIUS means Faster, Higher, Stronger.

questions.question: Name this dance: She is performing Mohiniyattam (ATTMAMONIHI). It is a classical dance form of Kerala.
questions.explanation: Mohiniyattam is a classical dance form of Kerala.

questions.question: Name this dance: Kuchipudi (PUDIIKUCH) is a classical dance of the state of Andhra Pradesh.
questions.explanation: Kuchipudi is a classical dance form of Andhra Pradesh.

questions.question: Name this dance: Kathakali (AHKLKTAAD) is a classical dance form of Kerala.
questions.explanation: Kathakali is a classical dance form of Kerala.

questions.question: Match the classical dance to its home state: Bharatanatyam
questions.explanation: Bharatanatyam is a classical dance form of Tamil Nadu.

questions.question: Match the classical dance to its home state: Manipuri
questions.explanation: Manipuri is a classical dance form of Manipur.

questions.question: Match the classical dance to its home state: Kuchipudi
questions.explanation: Kuchipudi is a classical dance form of Andhra Pradesh.

questions.question: Match the classical dance to its home state: Sattriya
questions.explanation: Sattriya is a classical dance form of Assam.

questions.question: Tick the correct dance: Male dancers wear a lot of make-up and huge headgear.
questions.explanation: Kathakali dancers are known for their elaborate make-up and headgear.

questions.question: Tick the correct dance: Rukmini Arundale is famous for this dance form.
questions.explanation: Rukmini Arundale is famous for reviving and popularizing Bharatanatyam.

questions.question: Tick the correct dance: A dance from north-eastern India.
questions.explanation: Manipuri is a classical dance form from north-eastern India.

questions.question: Tick the correct dance: You will see figures of these dancers on the walls of the temples in Odisha.
questions.explanation: Odissi dancers are depicted on the walls of temples in Odisha.

questions.question: Did You Know: The three syllables of Bha-ra-ta are short for bhava (expression), raga (melody), and tala (rhythm). Put them together and you get Bharatanatyam.
questions.explanation: The name Bharatanatyam comes from bhava (expression), raga (melody), and tala (rhythm).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: CHHATRAPATI SHIVAJI was a great Maratha warrior. He once escaped from his enemy's palace in a basket of fruits and sweets.
questions.explanation: Chhatrapati Shivaji was a great Maratha warrior known for his bravery and strategic escapes.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: LALA LAJPAT RAI was a great freedom fighter. He was known as Sher-e-Punjab, which means the Lion of Punjab.
questions.explanation: Lala Lajpat Rai was a freedom fighter known as Sher-e-Punjab, meaning the Lion of Punjab.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: BAL GANGADHAR TILAK was known for his fiery speeches. During the freedom struggle, he said, 'Swaraj is my birthright and I shall have it.'
questions.explanation: Bal Gangadhar Tilak was a freedom fighter known for his fiery speeches and the slogan, 'Swaraj is my birthright and I shall have it.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Dr. B. R. AMBEDKAR was a great Indian born on 14 April 1891. He was India's first law minister.
questions.explanation: Dr. B. R. Ambedkar was a great leader and India's first law minister, born on 14 April 1891.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: SARDAR PATEL's real name was Vallabhbhai. He was known as the Iron Man of India.
questions.explanation: Sardar Patel, whose real name was Vallabhbhai, was known as the Iron Man of India for his role in unifying the country.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: SAROJINI NAIDU was a freedom fighter and a great poet. She was known as the Nightingale of India.
questions.explanation: Sarojini Naidu was a freedom fighter and poet, known as the Nightingale of India.

questions.question: Match the city to the country and its famous monument: London
questions.explanation: London is in the UK, and its famous monument is Big Ben.

questions.question: Match the city to the country and its famous monument: Paris
questions.explanation: Paris is in France, and its famous monument is the Eiffel Tower.

questions.question: Match the city to the country and its famous monument: Pisa
questions.explanation: Pisa is in Italy, and its famous monument is the Leaning Tower of Pisa.

questions.question: Match the city to the country and its famous monument: San Francisco
questions.explanation: San Francisco is in the USA, and its famous monument is the Golden Gate Bridge.

questions.question: Match the city to the country and its famous monument: Sydney
questions.explanation: Sydney is in Australia, and its famous monument is the Sydney Opera House.

questions.question: Match the city to the country and its famous monument: Barcelona
questions.explanation: Barcelona is in Spain, and its famous monument is the Sagrada Familia.

questions.question: Match the description to the city: The capital of Thailand; many tourists visit it.
questions.explanation: Bangkok is the capital of Thailand and is known for its tourism.

questions.question: Match the description to the city: The city in the USA where many Hollywood movies are made.
questions.explanation: Los Angeles is the city in the USA where many Hollywood movies are made.

questions.question: Match the description to the city: Germany's capital city; it was once divided into two.
questions.explanation: Berlin is Germany's capital city and was once divided into East and West Berlin.

questions.question: Match the description to the city: A city in Italy which is well known for its canals.
questions.explanation: Venice is a city in Italy known for its canals.

questions.question: Match the description to the city: The capital city of Bangladesh which is very populated.
questions.explanation: Dhaka is the capital city of Bangladesh and is very populated.

questions.question: This aircraft goes into space.
questions.explanation: A spacecraft is designed to travel into space.

questions.question: The planets are named after Roman gods and goddesses. This one is named after the god of time.
questions.explanation: Saturn is named after the Roman god of time.

questions.question: As many as 1,300 Earths can fit inside this planet. It is huge.
questions.explanation: Jupiter is so large that about 1,300 Earths can fit inside it.

questions.question: It sounds like the name of a chocolate but is named after the Roman god of war.
questions.explanation: Mars is named after the Roman god of war.

questions.question: It is the brightest planet in the solar system. It is the only one that spins clockwise on its axis.
questions.explanation: Venus is the brightest planet and spins clockwise on its axis.

questions.question: This is the number of planets in the solar system.
questions.explanation: There are eight planets in the solar system.

questions.question: Neil Armstrong was the first man to set foot on it.
questions.explanation: Neil Armstrong was the first man to set foot on the Moon.

questions.question: This planet is named after the Roman God of the Sea.
questions.explanation: Neptune is named after the Roman god of the sea.

questions.question: It used to be called a planet till 2006.
questions.explanation: Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet in 2006.

questions.question: Uranus and Neptune contain a lot of this; in 2008-09 some has been found on Mars and on the Moon.
questions.explanation: Uranus and Neptune contain a lot of ice, which has also been found on Mars and the Moon.

questions.question: There is a belt full of these between Mars and Jupiter.
questions.explanation: The asteroid belt is located between Mars and Jupiter.

questions.question: Match the left column with the right: Team
questions.explanation: A team is led by a captain.

questions.question: Match the left column with the right: Aeroplane
questions.explanation: An aeroplane is led by a pilot, captain, or commander.

questions.question: Match the left column with the right: Committee
questions.explanation: A committee is led by a chairperson.

questions.question: Match the left column with the right: Orchestra
questions.explanation: An orchestra is led by a conductor.

questions.question: Match the left column with the right: Kingdom
questions.explanation: A kingdom is led by a king or queen.

questions.question: Match the left column with the right: Ship
questions.explanation: A ship is led by a captain or commander.

questions.question: Match the left column with the right: Army
questions.explanation: An army is led by a general or commander.

questions.question: Match the left column with the right: Newspaper/Magazine
questions.explanation: A newspaper or magazine is led by an editor.

questions.question: Match the left column with the right: Railway Station
questions.explanation: A railway station is managed by a station master.

questions.question: Match the left column with the right: Police Station
questions.explanation: A police station is managed by an officer-in-charge (OC).

questions.question: Match the left column with the right: Film/Play
questions.explanation: A film or play is led by a director.

questions.question: Match the left column with the right: Government
questions.explanation: A government is led by a prime minister or president.

questions.question: In your own Find Out book, make a list with the name of a person you know, beside each profession, like this: Doctor
questions.explanation: Example: Doctor - Dr. K. Sen

questions.explanation: Example: Pilot - Captain Ram Jha

questions.question: Will polar bears, penguins, and snow leopards be comfortable living in places near the equator?
questions.explanation: Polar bears, penguins, and snow leopards are adapted to cold climates and would not be comfortable near the equator.

questions.question: Which is the odd one out—diving, swimming, water polo, volleyball?
questions.explanation: Volleyball is not a water sport, while the others are.

questions.question: This famous statue of Jesus Christ in Brazil overlooks the city of Rio de Janeiro from a height of 706 meters. Name it.
questions.explanation: Christ the Redeemer is the famous statue located in Rio de Janeiro.

questions.question: Where will you find information about people, animals, and places—in a dictionary or in an encyclopaedia?
questions.explanation: An encyclopaedia contains comprehensive information about people, animals, and places.

questions.question: Guru Gobind Singh was the tenth and last Sikh... guru. Fill in the blank.
questions.explanation: Guru Gobind Singh was the tenth and last Sikh guru.

questions.question: How many countries can you travel to with the Schengen visa?
questions.explanation: You can travel to 26 countries with the Schengen visa.

questions.question: In which sport did Neeraj Chopra represent India at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics?
questions.explanation: Neeraj Chopra represented India in the Javelin throw at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.

questions.question: Rewrite this sentence correctly: 'We had some desert after dinner.'
options: We had some desert after dinner.
We had some dessert after dinner.
We had some desert before dinner.
We had some dessert before dinner.
questions.correct_answer: We had some dessert after dinner.
questions.explanation: The correct word is 'dessert,' which refers to a sweet dish eaten after a meal.

questions.explanation: Narendra Modi became the Prime Minister of India for the second time in 2019.

questions.explanation: Knives, forks, and spoons are part of cutlery.

questions.explanation: Manipuri is a classical dance form from the state of Manipur.

questions.explanation: Nelson Mandela, also known as 'Madiba,' was a great leader from South Africa who passed away in 2013.

questions.question: True or false: Beijing is the capital city of Japan.
questions.explanation: Beijing is the capital of China, not Japan.

questions.question: Is the machinery of a computer called its hardware or software?
questions.explanation: The machinery of a computer is called hardware.

questions.question: Which of the following is a spice?
questions.explanation: Cloves are aromatic flower buds used as a spice in cooking.

questions.question: Which of the following is a beverage?
questions.explanation: Coffee is a popular beverage consumed worldwide.

questions.question: Which of the following is a cereal?
questions.explanation: Rice is a staple cereal grain consumed as a main food in many cultures.

questions.question: Which of the following is crockery?
questions.explanation: Cups are a type of crockery used for holding beverages.

questions.question: Which of the following is stationery?
questions.explanation: Pencils are stationery items used for writing or drawing.

questions.question: Which of the following is cutlery?
questions.explanation: Knives are cutlery items used for cutting or eating food.

questions.question: Which of the things named on this page can you eat?
questions.explanation: Rice is an edible cereal grain that can be eaten.

questions.question: Which of the things named on this page can you drink?
questions.explanation: Coffee is a beverage that can be drunk.

questions.question: Which of the things named on this page can you use in school?
questions.explanation: Pencils are stationery items commonly used in school.

questions.question: Which of the things named on this page can you use at the dining table?
questions.explanation: Forks are cutlery items used at the dining table for eating.

questions.question: Who was the first woman President of India?
questions.explanation: Pratibha Patil was the first woman to serve as the President of India, holding the office from 2007 to 2012.

questions.question: Who was the first Vice President of India?
questions.explanation: Dr S. Radhakrishnan was the first Vice President of India, serving from 1952 to 1962.

questions.question: Who was the first and only Indian to win the Nobel Prize in Literature?
questions.explanation: Rabindranath Tagore was the first and only Indian to win the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1913.

questions.question: Who was the first Indian woman to climb Mount Everest?
questions.explanation: Bachendri Pal was the first Indian woman to climb Mount Everest in 1984.

questions.question: Who was the first Health Minister of India?
questions.explanation: Rajakumari Amrit Kaur was the first Health Minister of India, serving from 1947 to 1957.

questions.question: Who was the first Indian athlete to win an Olympic gold medal?
questions.explanation: Abhinav Bindra was the first Indian athlete to win an individual Olympic gold medal in shooting at the 2008 Beijing Olympics.

questions.question: Who was the first Indian scientist to win a Nobel Prize?
questions.explanation: Dr C. V. Raman was the first Indian scientist to win a Nobel Prize in Physics in 1930 for his work on light scattering.

questions.question: Who was the first Indian man in space?
questions.explanation: Rakesh Sharma was the first Indian man to travel to space in 1984 as part of a Soviet space mission.

questions.question: Who was the first woman IPS officer in India?
questions.explanation: Kiran Bedi was the first woman to join the Indian Police Service (IPS) in 1972.

questions.question: Who was the first Chief Minister of your state?
questions.explanation: The first Chief Minister of a state depends on the specific state in India. For example, in Maharashtra, it was Yashwantrao Chavan.

questions.question: Who was the first Principal of your school?
questions.explanation: The first Principal of a school depends on the specific school's history.

questions.question: Who was the first President of India?
questions.explanation: Dr Rajendra Prasad was the first President of India, serving from 1950 to 1962.

questions.question: Is appam and stew a delicacy in South India or North India?
questions.explanation: Appam and stew is a traditional dish from South India, particularly popular in Kerala and Tamil Nadu.

questions.question: In India, do we eat more mangoes in winter or in summer?
questions.explanation: Mangoes are a seasonal fruit in India, and they are primarily available and consumed during the summer months.

questions.question: Litti chokha is a popular food item in which of these states - Bihar, Haryana, or Nagaland?
questions.explanation: Litti chokha is a traditional dish from Bihar, made with roasted wheat balls (litti) and a mashed vegetable mix (chokha).

questions.question: Dabeli is a potato and bun-based snack with chutney and pomegranate. It is a popular dish in which of these states - Manipur, Karnataka, or Gujarat?
questions.explanation: Dabeli is a famous street food from Gujarat, known for its spicy and tangy flavors.

questions.question: Which of these does not contain rice - idli, biryani, pulao, dhokla, or dosa?
questions.explanation: Dhokla is made from fermented rice and chickpea flour, while the others (idli, biryani, pulao, dosa) are primarily rice-based dishes.

questions.question: Where do people eat more rice - in Rajasthan or Tamil Nadu?
questions.explanation: Rice is a staple food in Tamil Nadu, whereas Rajasthan's cuisine relies more on wheat and millets due to its arid climate.

questions.question: Pongal is an Indian rice dish. Pongal means 'boil' or 'bubbling up' in which of these languages - Tamil, Telugu, or Odia?
questions.explanation: Pongal is a traditional Tamil dish, and the word 'Pongal' in Tamil refers to the process of boiling or bubbling up.

questions.question: What is the common Indian (Hindi) name for cottage cheese?
questions.explanation: Paneer is the Hindi term for cottage cheese, widely used in Indian cuisine.

questions.question: Kangshoi is a vegetable stew eaten mainly by people in which of these states - Manipur, Goa, or Himachal Pradesh?
questions.explanation: Kangshoi is a traditional vegetable stew from Manipur, made with seasonal vegetables and flavored with local herbs.

questions.question: Which part of the cauliflower plant do we eat?
questions.explanation: Cauliflower is the flower of the plant, which is harvested and eaten.

questions.question: Which part of the coriander plant do we eat?
questions.explanation: Coriander leaves are commonly used as a herb in cooking.

questions.question: Which part of the turmeric plant do we eat?
questions.explanation: Turmeric is a rhizome, which is an underground stem, but it is commonly referred to as a root.

questions.question: Which part of the celery plant do we eat?
questions.explanation: Celery stalks, which are the stems of the plant, are commonly eaten.

questions.question: Which part of the ginger plant do we eat?
questions.explanation: Ginger is a rhizome, which is an underground stem, but it is commonly referred to as a root.

questions.question: Which part of the rice plant do we eat?
questions.explanation: Rice is the seed of the rice plant, which is harvested and consumed.

questions.question: Which part of the eucalyptus plant do we eat?
questions.explanation: Eucalyptus is not typically consumed as food; it is primarily used for its oil and medicinal properties.

questions.question: Which part of the lettuce plant do we eat?
questions.explanation: Lettuce leaves are commonly eaten in salads and other dishes.

questions.question: Which part of the sweet potato plant do we eat?
questions.explanation: Sweet potatoes are the tuberous roots of the plant, which are harvested and eaten.

questions.question: Which part of the radish plant do we eat?
questions.explanation: Radishes are the roots of the plant, which are commonly consumed.

questions.question: Which part of the mustard plant do we eat?
questions.explanation: Mustard seeds are used as a spice and for making mustard oil.

questions.question: Which part of the peas plant do we eat?
questions.explanation: Peas are the seeds of the plant, which are harvested and eaten.

questions.question: Which part of the potato plant do we eat?
questions.explanation: Potatoes are the tuberous stems of the plant, which are harvested and eaten.

questions.question: Which part of the onion plant do we eat?
questions.explanation: Onions are the bulbous leaves of the plant, which are commonly consumed.

questions.question: Which part of the spinach plant do we eat?
questions.explanation: Spinach leaves are commonly eaten as a leafy green vegetable.

questions.question: Which part of the garlic plant do we eat?
questions.explanation: Garlic is the bulb of the plant, which is commonly referred to as a root and used in cooking.

questions.question: Which part of the maize plant do we eat?
questions.explanation: Maize, or corn, is the seed of the plant, which is harvested and eaten.

questions.question: What do A. R. Rahman, Gulzar, Resul Pookutty, and Satyajit Ray have in common?
questions.explanation: A. R. Rahman, Gulzar, Resul Pookutty, and Satyajit Ray are all Indian personalities who have won Oscars for their contributions to cinema.

questions.question: What do Enid Blyton, J. K. Rowling, Lewis Carroll, Roald Dahl, and Sudha Murthy have in common?
questions.explanation: Enid Blyton, J. K. Rowling, Lewis Carroll, Roald Dahl, and Sudha Murthy are all renowned authors of children's books.

questions.question: What do Karna, Arjuna, Bhima, Draupadi, and Duryodhana have in common?
questions.explanation: Karna, Arjuna, Bhima, Draupadi, and Duryodhana are all characters from the Indian epic, the Mahabharata.

questions.question: What do George, Anne, Julian, Dick, and Timmy have in common?
questions.explanation: George, Anne, Julian, Dick, and Timmy are characters from the popular children's book series, The Famous Five, by Enid Blyton.

questions.question: What do Manpreet Singh, Sreejesh, Harmanpreet Singh, Rabichandra Singh Moirangthem, and Dipsan Tirkey have in common?
questions.explanation: Manpreet Singh, Sreejesh, Harmanpreet Singh, Rabichandra Singh Moirangthem, and Dipsan Tirkey are all Indian hockey players.

questions.question: What do Azim Premji, Anand Mahindra, Kiran Mazumdar-Shaw, Kumar Mangalam Birla, and Nisaba Godrej have in common?
questions.explanation: Azim Premji, Anand Mahindra, Kiran Mazumdar-Shaw, Kumar Mangalam Birla, and Nisaba Godrej are all prominent Indian businesspersons.

questions.question: What do Neeti Mohan, Neha Bhasin, Sunidhi Chauhan, Shreya Ghoshal, Sukhwinder Singh, and Arijit Singh have in common?
questions.explanation: Neeti Mohan, Neha Bhasin, Sunidhi Chauhan, Shreya Ghoshal, Sukhwinder Singh, and Arijit Singh are all popular Indian singers.

questions.question: What do Femina, The Week, India Today, Filmfare, and Champak have in common?
questions.explanation: Femina, The Week, India Today, Filmfare, and Champak are all well-known Indian magazines.

questions.category: The Environment, World and its People
questions.question: Where was Guru Nanak born?
questions.explanation: Guru Nanak, the founder of Sikhism, was born in Talwandi, which is now known as Nankana Sahib in present-day Pakistan.

questions.category: The Environment, World and its People
questions.question: Where was Lord Rama born?
questions.explanation: Lord Rama, a major deity in Hinduism, is believed to have been born in Ayodhya, India.

questions.category: The Environment, World and its People
questions.question: Where was Lord Krishna born?
questions.explanation: Lord Krishna, a major deity in Hinduism, is believed to have been born in Mathura, India.

questions.category: The Environment, World and its People
questions.question: Where was Prophet Muhammad born?
questions.explanation: Prophet Muhammad, the founder of Islam, was born in Mecca, Saudi Arabia.

questions.category: The Environment, World and its People
questions.question: Where was Gautama Buddha born?
questions.explanation: Gautama Buddha, the founder of Buddhism, was born in Lumbini, which is now in Nepal.

questions.category: The Environment, World and its People
questions.question: Where was Lord Jesus Christ born?
questions.explanation: Lord Jesus Christ, the central figure of Christianity, is believed to have been born in Bethlehem, in present-day Palestine.

questions.question: How many brains does an adult human being have?
questions.explanation: An adult human being has one brain, which controls all bodily functions.

questions.question: How many stomachs does an adult human being have?
questions.explanation: An adult human being has one stomach, which helps in digesting food.

questions.question: How many kidneys does an adult human being have?
questions.explanation: An adult human being has two kidneys, which filter waste from the blood.

questions.question: How many teeth does an adult human being have?
questions.explanation: An adult human being typically has 32 teeth, including wisdom teeth.

questions.question: How many hearts does an adult human being have?
questions.explanation: An adult human being has one heart, which pumps blood throughout the body.

questions.question: How many lungs does an adult human being have?
questions.explanation: An adult human being has two lungs, which help in breathing.

questions.question: Why do people who smoke have difficulty breathing?
questions.explanation: Smoking damages the lungs, making it difficult to breathe.

questions.question: What is the hard, outer covering of our teeth called?
questions.explanation: The hard, outer covering of our teeth is called enamel, which protects the teeth from decay.

questions.question: Which part of the body does a doctor hold to check your pulse?
questions.explanation: A doctor typically checks your pulse by holding your wrist.

questions.question: Which part of the body is affected by cataract?
questions.explanation: Cataract is a condition that affects the eyes, causing clouding of the lens.

questions.question: Which part of the body is affected by prickly heat?
questions.explanation: Prickly heat is a skin condition caused by blocked sweat glands.

questions.question: Which part of the body is affected by diarrhoea?
questions.explanation: Diarrhoea is a condition that affects the stomach and digestive system.

questions.question: Which part of the body is affected by migraine?
questions.explanation: Migraine is a type of headache that affects the head.

questions.question: Which part of the body is affected by a fracture?
questions.explanation: A fracture is a break or crack in a bone.

questions.question: Which part of the body is affected by tonsillitis?
questions.explanation: Tonsillitis is an inflammation of the tonsils, which are located in the throat.

questions.question: What should we drink plenty of for good health?
questions.explanation: Drinking plenty of water is essential for maintaining good health.

questions.question: How is it better to eat fruit?
questions.explanation: Eating fruit whole is better as it retains all its nutrients and fiber.

questions.question: What should we drink for strong bones?
questions.explanation: Milk is rich in calcium, which is essential for strong bones.

questions.question: What should we eat plenty of for good health?
questions.explanation: Eating plenty of vegetables is important for a balanced and healthy diet.

questions.question: Who invented the mobile phone?
questions.explanation: Martin Cooper is credited with inventing the first handheld mobile phone in 1973.

questions.question: Who invented the aeroplane?
questions.explanation: Orville and Wilbur Wright, also known as the Wright brothers, invented and flew the first successful aeroplane in 1903.

questions.question: Who invented the telegraph?
questions.explanation: Samuel Morse invented the telegraph and developed Morse code, a system of communication using dots and dashes.

questions.question: Who invented the electric light bulb?
questions.explanation: Thomas Edison is credited with inventing the practical electric light bulb in 1879.

questions.question: Who invented the telescope?
questions.explanation: Hans Lippershey is credited with inventing the telescope in 1608.

questions.question: Who invented the diesel engine?
questions.explanation: Rudolf Diesel invented the diesel engine in the late 19th century.

questions.question: Who invented the telephone?
questions.explanation: Alexander Graham Bell is credited with inventing the telephone in 1876.

questions.question: Complete the proverb: 'Never judge a book by its ______.'
questions.explanation: The proverb 'Never judge a book by its cover' means that you should not form an opinion about someone or something based solely on outward appearances.

questions.question: Complete the proverb: 'Actions speak ______ than words.'
questions.explanation: The proverb 'Actions speak louder than words' means that what someone does is more important than what they say.

questions.question: Complete the proverb: 'Out of sight, out of ______.'
questions.explanation: The proverb 'Out of sight, out of mind' means that when something is not visible or present, it is easily forgotten.

questions.question: Complete the proverb: 'A bird in hand is worth ______ in the bush.'
questions.explanation: The proverb 'A bird in hand is worth two in the bush' means that it is better to hold onto something you already have than to risk losing it by trying to get something more.

questions.question: Complete the proverb: 'Where there is a will, there is a ______.'
questions.explanation: The proverb 'Where there is a will, there is a way' means that if you are determined to do something, you will find a way to achieve it.

questions.question: Complete the simile: 'As hard as ______.'
questions.explanation: The simile 'As hard as rock' is used to describe something that is very hard or tough.

questions.question: Complete the simile: 'As busy as a ______.'
questions.explanation: The simile 'As busy as a bee' is used to describe someone who is very busy or active.

questions.question: Complete the simile: 'As cool as ______.'
questions.explanation: The simile 'As cool as ice' is used to describe someone who is very calm and composed.

questions.question: Complete the simile: 'As sly as a ______.'
questions.explanation: The simile 'As sly as a fox' is used to describe someone who is very cunning or clever.

questions.question: Complete the simile: 'As hungry as a ______.'
questions.explanation: The simile 'As hungry as a wolf' is used to describe someone who is very hungry.

questions.question: Complete the simile: 'As pretty as a ______.'
questions.explanation: The simile 'As pretty as a picture' is used to describe something or someone that is very beautiful.

questions.question: Complete the simile: 'As smooth as ______.'
questions.explanation: The simile 'As smooth as silk' is used to describe something that is very smooth and soft.

questions.question: Complete the simile: 'As heavy as ______.'
questions.explanation: The simile 'As heavy as lead' is used to describe something that is very heavy.

questions.question: Complete the simile: 'As clean as a ______.'
questions.explanation: The simile 'As clean as a whistle' is used to describe something that is very clean or spotless.

questions.question: Unscramble the letters for the answer: He/she helps the author to improve their written work such as a story, essay, poem, etc. (EDIOTR)
questions.explanation: An editor helps the author improve their written work.

questions.question: Unscramble the letters for the answer: A traditional short story that teaches a moral lesson. (ALFBE)
questions.explanation: A fable is a traditional short story that teaches a moral lesson.

questions.question: Unscramble the letters for the answer: The main printed part of a book/magazine. (XTTE)
questions.explanation: The text is the main printed part of a book or magazine.

questions.question: Unscramble the letters for the answer: A set of questions in a book to test your knowledge. (XCEESIRE)
questions.explanation: An exercise is a set of questions in a book to test your knowledge.

questions.question: Unscramble the letters for the answer: A word used for plays and theatre. (AADRM)
questions.explanation: Drama is a word used for plays and theatre.

questions.question: Unscramble the letters for the answer: The words of a song. (LYRCIS)
questions.explanation: Lyrics are the words of a song.

questions.question: Unscramble the letters for the answer: Many poems or stories together. (COTIONLLEC)
questions.explanation: A collection is many poems or stories together.

questions.question: Unscramble the letters for the answer: A writing partner. (OC-AUROTH)
questions.explanation: A co-author is a writing partner.

questions.question: In your own Find Out book, make a list like this: Who writes poems?
questions.explanation: A poet writes poems.

questions.question: In your own Find Out book, make a list like this: Who writes plays?
questions.explanation: A playwright writes plays.

questions.question: Find Out what these words mean: e-book, monograph, headline, caption, footnote.
questions.correct_answer: E-book: A digital version of a book; Monograph: A detailed written study on a single subject; Headline: The title of a news article; Caption: A brief explanation under a picture; Footnote: A note at the bottom of a page giving extra information.
questions.explanation: E-book: A digital version of a book; Monograph: A detailed written study on a single subject; Headline: The title of a news article; Caption: A brief explanation under a picture; Footnote: A note at the bottom of a page giving extra information.

questions.question: The Olympic symbol is five circles or rings joined together. What do the rings stand for?
questions.explanation: The five rings represent the five continents: Africa, Americas, Asia, Europe, and Oceania.

questions.question: What are the colors of the Olympic rings?
questions.explanation: The colors of the Olympic rings are blue, yellow, black, green, and red.

questions.question: Which Indian woman finished fourth in the golf event at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics?
questions.explanation: Aditi Ashok finished fourth in the golf event at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.

questions.question: Break dancing will be introduced as a new event in the Summer Olympics 2024. True or False.
questions.explanation: Break dancing will be introduced as a new event in the Summer Olympics 2024.

questions.question: Which country's team always marches last in the march past at the opening ceremony of the Olympics?
questions.explanation: The host country's team always marches last in the opening ceremony.

questions.question: Today's Olympic winners are presented with medals of gold, silver, or bronze. What were the winners in the ancient Olympics awarded?
questions.explanation: Winners in the ancient Olympics were awarded a crown of olive leaves.

questions.question: In which athletic event did Neeraj Chopra win a gold medal for India at the Tokyo Olympics 2020?
questions.explanation: Neeraj Chopra won a gold medal in the javelin throw at the Tokyo Olympics 2020.

questions.explanation: India has won eight Olympic golds, a silver, and three bronze medals in hockey.

questions.question: In which sport did Mirabai Chanu win a silver medal for India at the 2020 Tokyo Olympic Games?
questions.explanation: Mirabai Chanu won a silver medal in weightlifting at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.

questions.question: The Olympic motto is CITIUS, ALTIUS, FORTIUS. What does it mean?
questions.explanation: The Olympic motto CITIUS, ALTIUS, FORTIUS means Faster, Higher, Stronger.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: CHHATRAPATI SHIVAJI was a great Maratha warrior. He once escaped from his enemy's palace in a basket of fruits and sweets.

questions.explanation: Sardar Patel, whose real name was Vallabhbhai, was known as the Iron Man of India for his role in unifying the country.

questions.question: The planets are named after Roman gods and goddesses. This one is named after the god of time.
questions.explanation: Saturn is named after the Roman god of time.

questions.explanation: Jupiter is so large that about 1,300 Earths can fit inside it.

questions.explanation: Venus is the brightest planet and spins clockwise on its axis.

questions.explanation: A kingdom is led by a king or queen.

questions.question: Match the left column with the right: Ship
questions.explanation: A ship is led by a captain or commander.

questions.question: Match the left column with the right: Army
questions.explanation: An army is led by a general or commander.

questions.question: Match the left column with the right: Newspaper/Magazine
questions.explanation: A newspaper or magazine is led by an editor.

questions.question: Match the left column with the right: Railway Station
questions.explanation: A railway station is managed by a station master.

questions.question: Match the left column with the right: Police Station
questions.explanation: A police station is managed by an officer-in-charge (OC).

questions.question: Match the left column with the right: Film/Play
questions.explanation: A film or play is led by a director.

questions.question: Match the left column with the right: Government
questions.explanation: A government is led by a prime minister or president.

questions.question: In your own Find Out book, make a list with the name of a person you know, beside each profession, like this: Doctor
questions.explanation: Example: Doctor - Dr. K. Sen

questions.question: In your own Find Out book, make a list with the name of a person you know, beside each profession, like this: Pilot
questions.explanation: Example: Pilot - Captain Ram Jha

questions.question: Will polar bears, penguins, and snow leopards be comfortable living in places near the equator?
questions.explanation: Polar bears, penguins, and snow leopards are adapted to cold climates and would not be comfortable near the equator.

questions.question: Which is the odd one out—diving, swimming, water polo, volleyball?
questions.explanation: Volleyball is not a water sport, while the others are.

questions.question: This famous statue of Jesus Christ in Brazil overlooks the city of Rio de Janeiro from a height of 706 meters. Name it.
questions.explanation: Christ the Redeemer is the famous statue located in Rio de Janeiro.

questions.question: Where will you find information about people, animals, and places—in a dictionary or in an encyclopaedia?
questions.explanation: An encyclopaedia contains comprehensive information about people, animals, and places.

questions.question: Guru Gobind Singh was the tenth and last Sikh... guru. Fill in the blank.
questions.explanation: Guru Gobind Singh was the tenth and last Sikh guru.

questions.question: How many countries can you travel to with the Schengen visa?
questions.explanation: You can travel to 26 countries with the Schengen visa.

questions.question: In which sport did Neeraj Chopra represent India at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics?
questions.explanation: Neeraj Chopra represented India in the Javelin throw at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics.

questions.question: Rewrite this sentence correctly: 'We had some desert after dinner.'
options: We had some desert after dinner.
We had some dessert after dinner.
We had some desert before dinner.
We had some dessert before dinner.
questions.correct_answer: We had some dessert after dinner.
questions.explanation: The correct word is 'dessert,' which refers to a sweet dish eaten after a meal.

questions.question: Who became the Prime Minister of India for the second time in 2019?
questions.explanation: Narendra Modi became the Prime Minister of India for the second time in 2019.

questions.question: Are knives, forks, and spoons part of cutlery or crockery?
questions.explanation: Knives, forks, and spoons are part of cutlery.

questions.question: A. R. Rahman and Resul Pookutty have won the O .G.A.R. 5 (film awards). Fill in the blanks.
questions.explanation: A. R. Rahman and Resul Pookutty have won Oscars, which are prestigious film awards.

questions.question: If you add the letter 'i' at the end of the name of a state, you get the name of an Indian classical dance. Name the state.
questions.explanation: Manipuri is a classical dance form from the state of Manipur.

questions.question: In South Africa, they called him 'Madiba'. A great leader, he passed away in 2013. Name him.
questions.explanation: Nelson Mandela, also known as 'Madiba,' was a great leader from South Africa who passed away in 2013.

questions.question: Who were known as 'the Lion of Punjab'; 'Nightingale of India'; and 'Iron Man of India'?
options: Lala Lajpat Rai, Sarojini Naidu, Sardar Patel
Bhagat Singh, Indira Gandhi, B. R. Ambedkar
Bal Gangadhar Tilak, Rani Lakshmibai, Subhas Chandra Bose
Jawaharlal Nehru, Mother Teresa, Dr. Rajendra Prasad
questions.correct_answer: Lala Lajpat Rai, Sarojini Naidu, Sardar Patel
questions.explanation: Lala Lajpat Rai is known as the Lion of Punjab, Sarojini Naidu as the Nightingale of India, and Sardar Patel as the Iron Man of India.

questions.question: True or false: Beijing is the capital city of Japan.
questions.explanation: Beijing is the capital of China, not Japan.

questions.question: Is the machinery of a computer called its hardware or software?
questions.explanation: The machinery of a computer is called hardware.

questions.question: Martin Cooper gave the world its first Mobile... phone. Fill in the blank.
questions.explanation: Martin Cooper invented the first mobile phone.

questions.question: All living things are most comfortable in their homes or natural habitats. Fill in the blank.
questions.explanation: All living things are most comfortable in their natural habitats.

questions.question: Lord Jesus Christ was born in Bethlehem (EELHEMTBH) and Lord Krishna was born in ....Mathura (AMURHTA).
questions.explanation: Jesus Christ was born in Bethlehem, and Lord Krishna was born in Mathura.

questions.question: Whom did Droupadi Murmu succeed as the president of India?
questions.explanation: Droupadi Murmu succeeded Ram Nath Kovind as the president of India.
